importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating when the White House announced its plan to use tariff revenue to fund WIC during the government shutdown.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame during which the federal government shutdown occurred, and the immediate response by the Trump administration to keep the WIC program operational.

keyTakeAways: The White House announced it would use Section 32 tariff revenue — typically designated for child nutrition — to fund WIC during the government shutdown.
This funding shift was made to prevent WIC from shutting down after Congress failed to pass a spending bill for fiscal year 2026.
WIC serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new moms, and young children, providing essential nutrition support such as infant formula, fruits, vegetables, and breastfeeding guidance.
The National WIC Association expressed concern over uncertainty regarding funding amounts, speed of disbursement, and duration of support.
Legal experts question the administration’s authority to redirect tariff revenue to WIC, noting that Congress has not appropriated funds for the program.
The move reflects bipartisan concern over the impact of the shutdown on vulnerable populations, with Republicans like House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democrats for politicizing the shutdown.
Tariff revenue, including Section 232 tariffs, has totaled $190 billion so far this year, with Trump’s administration using a portion for emergency WIC support.
Funding for WIC is capped at $7.6 billion annually, but advocates stress the need for increased support to avoid cuts and ensure no families are turned away.
The program's enrollment has increased to nearly 6.9 million, showing growing demand amid rising inflation and economic hardship.

namedEntities.name: White House
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The executive branch office of the U.S. President, responsible for policy implementation and public communication.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The White House announced and justified the use of tariff revenue to fund WIC during the government shutdown, demonstrating executive action in times of fiscal crisis.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program providing nutrition support to pregnant women, new moms, and young children.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIC is central to the article, as the shutdown threatened its closure, and the administration's plan directly targets its continued operation.

namedEntities.name: Section 32 tariff revenue
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariff revenue designated for child nutrition programs, such as WIC, under federal policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This revenue stream is specifically redirected to keep WIC funded during the shutdown, highlighting a strategic financial reallocation.

namedEntities.name: Section 232 tariffs
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Tariffs imposed on imports for national security reasons, such as steel, aluminum, and cars.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article references a shift from using Section 232 revenue to Section 32 revenue, indicating a legal and policy debate over tariff fund allocation.

namedEntities.name: President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The 45th President of the United States, who has pursued protectionist trade policies and increased tariffs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the policy decision, as his administration initiated and communicated the tariff-funded WIC plan during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Congress
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The legislative body responsible for federal budgeting and appropriations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Congress’s failure to pass a spending bill triggered the shutdown and created the funding gap that the White House attempted to address.

namedEntities.name: House Speaker Mike Johnson
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The current Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, a Republican leader.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He criticized Democrats for causing the shutdown and highlighted the harm to vulnerable populations like WIC beneficiaries.

namedEntities.name: National WIC Association
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The advocacy group representing WIC program stakeholders.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It expressed both support and skepticism about the tariff funding solution, emphasizing the need for transparency and long-term stability.

namedEntities.name: Chris Towner
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Policy director at the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He raised concerns about the legality of redirecting tariff funds without congressional appropriation.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal department responsible for agricultural policy and food assistance programs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The USDA confirmed WIC’s funding lapse and announced contingency funds for states during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Axios
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. news and analysis website.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Axios first reported the White House’s tariff funding plan, indicating media coverage and public awareness of the policy.

namedEntities.name: Samantha Waldenberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is one of the journalists who reported on the policy decision, contributing to the article’s coverage.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is another journalist involved in reporting on the White House’s decision to fund WIC during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Georgia Machell
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: CEO of the National WIC Association.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She provided a statement criticizing the lack of clarity in the funding plan, emphasizing the need for stability.

namedEntities.name: Fiscal Year 2026
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The federal fiscal year starting on October 1, 2025, during which Congress failed to pass a spending package.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This year’s funding gap led to the shutdown and the urgent need for alternative funding for WIC.

namedEntities.name: Infant formula manufacturers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Companies that produce infant formula, which are cited as a source of state-level funding for WIC.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: States can use rebates from these manufacturers to supplement WIC funding during the funding lapse.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During the ongoing government shutdown in October 2025, the White House announced it would redirect tariff revenue — specifically from Section 32 funds intended for child nutrition — to sustain the WIC program, which serves nearly 7 million pregnant women, new mothers, and young children. This decision follows Congress’s failure to pass a funding bill for fiscal year 2026, threatening to cut off WIC operations. The move was framed by the White House as a necessary and creative response to protect vulnerable families, though legal experts and advocacy groups express concern over transparency, funding stability, and the lack of congressional appropriation. While the National WIC Association welcomed the effort, it emphasized uncertainty around funding amounts, disbursement timelines, and long-term viability. The administration’s plan leverages existing tariff collections — which have reached $190 billion so far — to avoid program collapse, but its legality remains under scrutiny. The situation underscores broader concerns about how political gridlock impacts essential public services, with bipartisan figures like House Speaker Mike Johnson criticizing Democratic leaders for deepening the crisis.
title: White House says it will use tariff revenue to fund federal food aid for mothers and young children
